elements.content: A mixture of 2D and 1D metal–organic complexes, [ZnL­(H2O)2·G1·DEF·2H2O] n (1a: G1 = naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate; DEF = N,N-diethylformamide) and [ZnL­(H2O)3·G1·DEF·2H2O] n (2), has been prepared from a hydrogenated Schiff base L and Zn­(II) in a DEF-contained solvent system under mild conditions. The yields of 1a and 2 are equivalent; however, they can be tuned by varying the amount of DEF solvent. Increasing the use of DEF tends to form pure 1a, while decreasing it generates 2. Without DEF, another novel 3D four-connected CdSO4 (cds) framework [ZnL­(H2O)2·G1·2H2O] n (3) composed of alternated right-handed and left-handed helical chains has been constructed. The amount of DEF solvent has a significant impact on the diverse coordination architectures of 1–3, which is rare in the preparation of metal–organic complexes. The photoluminescence of complexes 1–3 along with naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate has been investigated in the solid state. The luminescent emission of G1 was enhanced greatly after being confined into metal–organic networks. In addition, complexes 1–3 display second-harmonic generation efficiencies, which are approximately 0.58, 0.42, 0.32, and 0.52 times as much as that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate.

The yields of 1a and 2 are equivalent; however, they can be tuned by varying the amount of DEF solvent. Increasing the use of DEF tends to form pure 1a, while decreasing it generates 2. Without DEF, another novel 3D four-connected CdSO4 (cds) framework [ZnL(H2O)2⋅G1⋅2H2O] n  (3) composed of alternated right-handed and left-handed helical chains has been constructed. The amount of DEF solvent has a significant impact on the diverse coordination architectures of 1-3, which is rare in the preparation of metal-organic complexes. The photoluminescence of complexes 1-3 along with naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate has been investigated in the solid state. The luminescent emission of G1 was enhanced greatly after being confined into metal-organic networks. In addition, complexes 1-3 display second-harmonic generation efficiencies, which are approximately 0.58, 0.42, 0.32, and 0.52 times as much as that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate.

elements.content: Three metal−organic complexes, a 2D network, a 1D linear chain, and a 3D cds-topological framework, have been prepared from a hydrogenated Schiff base ligand and Zn­(II). The constructions of such diverse structures are controlled by the amount of DEF solvent. In addition, these complexes exhibit photoluminescent and NLO properties.

The constructions of such diverse structures are controlled by the amount of DEF solvent. In addition, these complexes exhibit photoluminescent and NLO properties.

elements.content: The rational design and synthesis of metal–organic complexes (MOCs) or coordination polymers (CPs) are of great interest due to their intriguing architectures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in material storage, delivery, catalysis, luminescence, separation, sensing, and so on. Applying crystal engineering, numerous MOCs with predetermined structures and properties have been prepared from appropriate organic ligands (single or mixed ligands) and metal centers. Nonetheless, in a real chemical reaction, the other factors such as solvents, templates, counterions, temperature, pH, and concentration have an unpredictable impact on the structural prediction of the final frameworks as well. Many examples of solvent-dependent formation of MOCs have been reported. The solvent influence on the crystalline products can be concluded in the following ways: (i) solvents participate in coordination; (ii) solvents act as guests or structure-directing agent; or (iii) both. However, the mechanism of solvent effect is still poorly understood. From this point, further study of the solvent effects in the construction of MOCs is essential.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and synthesis of metal-organic complexes (MOCs) or coordination polymers (CPs) are of great interest due to their intriguing architectures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in material storage, delivery, catalysis, luminescence, separation, sensing, and so on. Applying crystal engineering, numerous MOCs with predetermined structures and properties have been prepared from appropriate organic ligands (single or mixed ligands) and metal centers. Nonetheless, in a real chemical reaction, the other factors such as solvents, templates, counterions, temperature, pH, and concentration have an unpredictable impact on the structural prediction of the final frameworks as well. Many examples of solvent-dependent formation of MOCs have been reported. The solvent influence on the crystalline products can be concluded in the following ways: (i) solvents participate in coordination; (ii) solvents act as guests or structure-directing agent; or (iii) both. However, the mechanism of solvent effect is still poorly understood. From this point, further study of the solvent effects in the construction of MOCs is essential.

elements.content: Schiff bases are important N-donor ligands in coordination chemistry, which have been used broadly to construct various metal–organic complexes. Their reduced products, hydrogenated (or reduced) Schiff bases, with increased N basicity and framework flexibility (C–N vs CN), might coordinate to metal ions more easily and diversely, so they have gained more and more attention in recent years. 1,2-Bis­(4′-pyridylmethylamino)­ethane (L), a functional tetradentate hydrogenated Schiff base, derived easily from ethylenediamine and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde, has been applied to assembly with Ag­(I), Cu­(I), Cu­(II), and Cd­(II). Besides the metals, the counterions also play an important role in the structural assembly process. Usually, L tends to compose 1D hinged chains and 2D cationic networks in these examples. In order to further develop the related research, we focus our studies on the synthesis of L-based MOCs with more diverse frameworks (3D to 1D). In this work, employing naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate as the guest molecule (or counterion), 1D to 3D and chiral to noncentrosymmetric MOCs 1–3 are prepared from L and Zn­(ClO4)2, which is controlled by the amount of N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) solvent. Moreover, the photoluminescent and nonlinear optical (NLO) properties are also studied.

elements.content: Disodium naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate, Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O, and solvents were purchased commercially and used directly. The hydrogenated Schiff base L was synthesized according to the literature procedure. All manipulations were carried out under aerobic and mild conditions. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed with a Vario MICRO CHNOS elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra with a KBr pellet were recorded in the range 4000–400 cm–1 on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. The solid-state luminescence emission/excitation spectra were recorded on an FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a DMAX-2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra were conducted on a Jasco J-810 spectrodichrometer. Second harmonic generation (SHG) measurements on powder samples of MOCs 1–3 and potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) were carried out by the Kurtz and Perry method using a Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Disodium naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate, Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, and solvents were purchased commercially and used directly. The hydrogenated Schiff base L was synthesized according to the literature procedure. All manipulations were carried out under aerobic and mild conditions. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed with a Vario MICRO CHNOS elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra with a KBr pellet were recorded in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. The solid-state luminescence emission/excitation spectra were recorded on an FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a DMAX-2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra were conducted on a Jasco J-810 spectrodichrometer. Second harmonic generation (SHG) measurements on powder samples of MOCs 1-3 and potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) were carried out by the Kurtz and Perry method using a Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm).

Synthesis of [ZnL­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>·G1·DEF·2H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1a</bold>)

A solution of L (48 mg, 0.2 mmol) and Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O (74 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O/EtOH (6 mL/3 mL) was stirred for 10 min. Then, 3 mL of DEF and a solution of naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate (G1) (66 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (4.5 mL) was added. After 10 min, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate was slowly evaporated for 5 days to yield colorless crystals. Yield: 68 mg, 44%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C29H43N5O11S2Zn: C 45.40, H 5.65, N 9.13. elements.content: The X-ray single-crystal structure analyses for the compounds were performed on a Rigaku SCXmini diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.710 73 Å, graphite monochromator) at 293(2) K. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL-97 program. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were located at their ideal positions. Crystal data for 1–3 are presented in . Selected bond lengths and angles of 1–3 are listed in Tables S1–S3 of the Supporting Information.

Single-Crystal Structure Determination

The X-ray single-crystal structure analyses for the compounds were performed on a Rigaku SCXmini diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, graphite monochromator) at 293(2) K. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL-97 program. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were located at their ideal positions. Crystal data for 1-3 are presented in . Selected bond lengths and angles of 1-3 are listed in Tables S1-S3 of the Supporting Information.

Crystal 1a can be obtained easily from the DEF-containing solvent; however, its structure is unable to be solved fully although many methods have been tried. So, we prepared its analogue 1b by just changing DEF with DMA. The structures of 1a and 1b are similar according to the crystal data, PXRD patterns, TGA curve, IR, and element analysis. So the structural description of 1a was represented by that of 1b. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that MOC 1b crystallizes in the monoclinic space group Pc. Its asymmetric unit consists of one Zn­(II), one L, one G1, one DMA, and two coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (a). Zn­(II) ions are six-coordinated by two O atoms (O1 and O2) of two water molecules and four N atoms (N1, N2, N3a, and N4b) of three different L ligands, forming a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The bond lengths of the two Zn–O are 2.155(6) and 2.255(5) Å, and the Zn–N distances vary from 2.121(6) to 2.190(6) Å, respectively. The Zn···Zn distances spanned by half of one L ligand are 9.4 Å. The bond angles around Zn­(II) ions are 81.9(3)° to 178.2(3)°. L exhibits a “V” shape and functions as a bridging linker, resulting in a 2D layer with rhombic windows (b). Naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate molecules are intercalated orderly in the interlayer space (c), and the interlayer distance of two adjacent layers is 9.4 Å (Figure S1a, Supporting Information). Different sulfonates and coordinated and uncoordinated waters are connected via intermolecular hydrogen bonds (the distances of O···O varied from 2.60 to 2.93 Å) to compose a supermolecular layer (d). Each DMA solvent molecule is restricted in every window of layered 1b through π–π stacking interactions (3.83 Å) of CO in DMA and the two nearest pyridine rings in the L ligand (Figure S1b, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

Crystal Structure of [ZnL(H2O)2⋅G1⋅DEF⋅2H2O] n  (1a) and [ZnL(H2O)2⋅G1⋅DMA⋅2H2O] n  (1b)

Crystal 1a can be obtained easily from the DEF-containing solvent; however, its structure is unable to be solved fully although many methods have been tried. So, we prepared its analogue 1b by just changing DEF with DMA. The structures of 1a and 1b are similar according to the crystal data, PXRD patterns, TGA curve, IR, and element analysis. So the structural description of 1a was represented by that of 1b. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that MOC 1b crystallizes in the monoclinic space group Pc. Its asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II), one L, one G1, one DMA, and two coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (a). Zn(II) ions are six-coordinated by two O atoms (O1 and O2) of two water molecules and four N atoms (N1, N2, N3a, and N4b) of three different L ligands, forming a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The bond lengths of the two Zn-O are 2.155(6) and 2.255(5) Å, and the Zn-N distances vary from 2.121(6) to 2.190(6) Å, respectively. The Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances spanned by half of one L ligand are 9.4 Å. The bond angles around Zn(II) ions are 81.9(3)° to 178.2(3)°. L exhibits a "V" shape and functions as a bridging linker, resulting in a 2D layer with rhombic windows (b). Naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate molecules are intercalated orderly in the interlayer space (c), and the interlayer distance of two adjacent layers is 9.4 Å (Figure S1a, Supporting Information). Different sulfonates and coordinated and uncoordinated waters are connected via intermolecular hydrogen bonds (the distances of O⋅⋅⋅O varied from 2.60 to 2.93 Å) to compose a supermolecular layer (d). Each DMA solvent molecule is restricted in every window of layered 1b through π-π stacking interactions (3.83 Å) of CO in DMA and the two nearest pyridine rings in the L ligand (Figure S1b, Supporting Information).

(c) 3D structure of 1b viewed down the b-axis. (d) Supermolecular layer composed of sulfonate and water through hydrogen-bonding interactions (red dashed lines represent the hydrogen bonds).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic space group P21, with Flack parameters of 0.02(1). The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn­(II), one L, one G1, one DEF, and three coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (a). All Zn­(II) atoms adopt a distorted octahedral coordination geometry completed by one O atom from water (O3) and three N atoms from two L’s (N1, N2, and N4a) composing the equatorial plane, and two O (O1 and O2) atoms from two water molecules at the apical positions. The bonds lengths are Zn–N = 2.133(2)–2.261(2) Å and Zn–O = 2.100(2)–2.167(2) Å. The Zn···Zn distances are 9.4 Å. Ligand L shows a “V” shape; however, it functions as a linear linker differing from 1b, because one of the pyridyl groups in L does not take part in coordination. As a result, a chain of 2 is constructed from tridentate L and Zn­(II) (b). Different chains, G1, DEF, and water molecules are connected together to form a 3D framework through the intermolecular hydrogen bonds (the distances of O···O varied from 2.64 to 2.90 Å and O···N is 2.98 Å) (Figure S2a, Supporting Information). There exist π–π interactions between CO of DEF and G1 (3.8 Å) (Figure S2b, Supporting Information). Complex 2 is chiral and was self-assemblied from totally achiral precursors by spontaneous resolution. A single crystal is homochiral; however, the bulk samples may be conglomerates. Therefore, we tried hard to get the other enantiomer. Fortunately, another crystal, 2X, was picked out, the structure of which has a “mirror symmetry” with 2, which indicated that they are supramolecular enantiomers (c vs d). The solid-state CD spectra of 2 and 2X were studied, and the results were in good accord with the structures obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S2c, Supporting Information).

Crystal Structure of [ZnL(H2O)3⋅G1⋅DEF⋅2H2O] n  (2)

Complex 2 crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic space group P21, with Flack parameters of 0.02(1). The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II), one L, one G1, one DEF, and three coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (a). All Zn(II) atoms adopt a distorted octahedral coordination geometry completed by one O atom from water (O3) and three N atoms from two L's (N1, N2, and N4a) composing the equatorial plane, and two O (O1 and O2) atoms from two water molecules at the apical positions. The bonds lengths are Zn-N = 2.133(2)-2.261(2) Å and Zn-O = 2.100(2)-2.167(2) Å. The Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances are 9.4 Å. Ligand L shows a "V" shape; however, it functions as a linear linker differing from 1b, because one of the pyridyl groups in L does not take part in coordination. As a result, a chain of 2 is constructed from tridentate L and Zn(II) (b). Different chains, G1, DEF, and water molecules are connected together to form a 3D framework through the intermolecular hydrogen bonds (the distances of O⋅⋅⋅O varied from 2.64 to 2.90 Å and O⋅⋅⋅N is 2.98 Å) (Figure S2a, Supporting Information). There exist π-π interactions between CO of DEF and G1 (3.8 Å) (Figure S2b, Supporting Information). Complex 2 is chiral and was self-assemblied from totally achiral precursors by spontaneous resolution. A single crystal is homochiral; however, the bulk samples may be conglomerates. Therefore, we tried hard to get the other enantiomer. Fortunately, another crystal, 2X, was picked out, the structure of which has a "mirror symmetry" with 2, which indicated that they are supramolecular enantiomers (c vs d). The solid-state CD spectra of 2 and 2X were studied, and the results were in good accord with the structures obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S2c, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group Cc. Its asymmetric unit consists of one Zn­(II), one L, one G1, and two coordinated and two uncoordinated water molecules (a). All the Zn­(II) ions in complex 3 are six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, N3a, and N4b) of three different L ligands and two oxygen atoms (O1, O2) from two waters to afford the distorted octahedral geometry ZnN4O2. The bond lengths of Zn–O are 2.148(3) and 2.208(3) Å, and the Zn–N distances are 2.146(4) to 2.258(3) Å, respectively. The Zn···Zn distances spanned by half of an L ligand are 9.3 and 9.5 Å. The bond angles around each Zn­(II) ion vary from 81.5(1)° to 174.7(1)°. Ligand L exhibits also a “V” shape, but its distorting extent is much different from that of 1 and 2. As a result, a 3D framework is observed (b), which is composed of alternated right-handed and left-handed helical chains with pitches of 9.4 Å along the a-axis (c). Topologically, the 3D network of 3 can be described as a four-connected CdSO4 (cds) net with a point symbol {65.8} (d). Naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate guests are located in the channels through intermolecular hydrogen bonds between sulfonates and water molecules (the distances of O···O are 2.71 and 2.98 Å) (e and S3).

elements.content: MOCs 1–3 were prepared from ligand L, Zn­(II), and naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate under mild conditions. It is noteworthy that the solvent has a great influence on the structural assembly and prediction of polymeric frameworks. When 2 mL of DEF was added to the solution of substrates in H2O/EtOH (10.5 mL/3 mL), a mixture of crystals 1a and 2 was produced. They can be separated by hand, as their appearances are much different from each other (Figure S4, Supporting Information), and their yields are similar. Intriguingly, the formation of 2 was prohibited by increasing the amount of DEF solvent. Almost pure 1a was collected when 3 mL of DEF was added. On further increasing the DEF amount, only 1a was formed. On the contrary, reduction of the amount of DEF led to the decrease of 1a, and pure 2 has been observed when 1 mL of DEF was used. The less DEF condition is prone to forming 2. In addition, a minor variation of the amount of H2O and EtOH did not affect the self-assembly process. Without DEF solvent, a novel 3D framework, 3, was obtained. Thus, the formation of diverse structures of 1–3 was controlled by the amount of DEF (). The steric effect of DEF plays an important role in this structure-directing activity; moreover, the minor variations of solubility, density, acidity/basicity, etc., of solvents may also have an immense effect on the self-assembly process.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOCs 1-3 and Comparison of the Structures

MOCs 1-3 were prepared from ligand L, Zn(II), and naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate under mild conditions. It is noteworthy that the solvent has a great influence on the structural assembly and prediction of polymeric frameworks. When 2 mL of DEF was added to the solution of substrates in H2O/EtOH (10.5 mL/3 mL), a mixture of crystals 1a and 2 was produced. They can be separated by hand, as their appearances are much different from each other (Figure S4, Supporting Information), and their yields are similar. Intriguingly, the formation of 2 was prohibited by increasing the amount of DEF solvent. Almost pure 1a was collected when 3 mL of DEF was added. On further increasing the DEF amount, only 1a was formed. On the contrary, reduction of the amount of DEF led to the decrease of 1a, and pure 2 has been observed when 1 mL of DEF was used. The less DEF condition is prone to forming 2. In addition, a minor variation of the amount of H2O and EtOH did not affect the self-assembly process. Without DEF solvent, a novel 3D framework, 3, was obtained. Thus, the formation of diverse structures of 1-3 was controlled by the amount of DEF (). The steric effect of DEF plays an important role in this structure-directing activity; moreover, the minor variations of solubility, density, acidity/basicity, etc., of solvents may also have an immense effect on the self-assembly process.

elements.content: In order to compare the structures of 1–3, the different conformations of L in 1–3 are first described (). In 1, bonds N2–C3 and N1–C9 are both located on the same side and the dihedral angle of the two pyridines is 82.9(1)°. As a result, L tends to construct a rhombus window, which leads to a 2D layer of 1. Much different from 1, bonds N2–C3 and N1–C9 in 2 are on the anti side, and the dihedral angle of the two pyridines is only 60.9(1)°, which cause ligand L to compose a grid with difficulty. Therefore, a linear chain of 2 is formed. Similar to 2, bonds N2–C3 and N1–C9 of L in 3 are on the anti side, but the dihedral angle of the two pyridines is 81.2(1)°. The conformation of L is not fit for them to form a window; however, they can be linked together in a staggered mode to construct a 3D framework. These varied conformations of L and structural frameworks of 1–3 are tuned by just changing the amount of DEF solvent during the self-assembly process, which is rare in the field of coordination chemistry, and it may provide a new perspective to the rational design and synthesis of diverse crystalline materials.

elements.content: In order to confirm the phase purity of these complexes, the PXRD patterns were recorded for MOCs 1 to 3. The experimental PXRD patterns of MOCs 1–3 are in good agreement with the simulated ones calculated from the single-crystal diffraction data (Figures S5–S7, Supporting Information), indicating that they are in a pure phase. Moreover, the thermogravimetric (TG) measurements were performed in a N2 atmosphere to examine the thermal stability. TG curves of MOCs 1–3 are shown in Figures S8–S11 (Supporting Information). MOCs 1–3 remained stable up to 311, 308, 318, and 274 °C, respectively. The TGA curve of complex 1a indicated that the loss of H2O and DEF molecules occurred between 85 and 286 °C (found 21.1%, calcd 21.8%), while the loss of H2O and DMA molecules in 1b occurred between 81 and 273 °C (found 20.8%, calcd 21.1%). In complex 2, a weight loss of 24.0% (calcd 24.3%) was observed with respect to the losses of water and DEF molecules between 65 and 271 °C, while a weight loss of 11.1% (calcd 10.8%) between 56 and 167 °C was observed for 3 with respect to the loss of water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stabilities and Powder X-ray Diffraction of the Complexes 1-3 

In order to confirm the phase purity of these complexes, the PXRD patterns were recorded for MOCs 1 to 3. The experimental PXRD patterns of MOCs 1-3 are in good agreement with the simulated ones calculated from the single-crystal diffraction data (Figures S5-S7, Supporting Information), indicating that they are in a pure phase. Moreover, the thermogravimetric (TG) measurements were performed in a N2 atmosphere to examine the thermal stability. TG curves of MOCs 1-3 are shown in Figures S8-S11 (Supporting Information). MOCs 1-3 remained stable up to 311, 308, 318, and 274 °C, respectively. The TGA curve of complex 1a indicated that the loss of H2O and DEF molecules occurred between 85 and 286 °C (found 21.1%, calcd 21.8%), while the loss of H2O and DMA molecules in 1b occurred between 81 and 273 °C (found 20.8%, calcd 21.1%). In complex 2, a weight loss of 24.0% (calcd 24.3%) was observed with respect to the losses of water and DEF molecules between 65 and 271 °C, while a weight loss of 11.1% (calcd 10.8%) between 56 and 167 °C was observed for 3 with respect to the loss of water molecules.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of MOCs 1–3 together with naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate were investigated under ambient temperature. Upon excitation at 276 nm, strong emission bands centered at 342 and 358 nm were detected, which were similar to the emissions of naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate. So, the emissions of 1–3 may be assigned to the intraligand charge transition of sulfonate. The external quantum yields (Φf) of MOCs 1a, 1b, 2, and 3 were determined by means of an integrating sphere and found to be 20.3%, 14.3%, 19.7%, and 12.2%, respectively, which were much higher than that of disodium naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate (Φf = 7.7%). The enhancement of luminescence of 1–3 compared to G1 can be analyzed from their crystal structures. In MOCs 1–3, G1 molecules were distributed orderly in the interlayer region, between polymer chains, or in the void of the 3D framework, which prohibited the aggregation-caused quenching of fluorophores. The different fluorescence intensity for MOCs 1–3 may be due to the different arrangements of G1 in 1–3. In MOC 1, naphthalene-2,7-disulfonates were confined between neighboring layers to form a flat layer through hydrogen-bonding interactions (d); G1 in 2 composed a 2D layer (Figure S2a), while in 3, G1’s were connected together to generate a 3D structure (Figure S3). Hence, we provided herein an effective methodology to design and prepare luminescent materials by introducing fluorescent guest compounds into MOCs to obstruct the formation of luminophoric aggregates. If proper MOC and functional guests were combined together efficiently, more and more potential luminescent hybrid materials should be prepared.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

The photoluminescent properties of MOCs 1-3 together with naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate were investigated under ambient temperature. Upon excitation at 276 nm, strong emission bands centered at 342 and 358 nm were detected, which were similar to the emissions of naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate. So, the emissions of 1-3 may be assigned to the intraligand charge transition of sulfonate. The external quantum yields (Φf) of MOCs 1a, 1b, 2, and 3 were determined by means of an integrating sphere and found to be 20.3%, 14.3%, 19.7%, and 12.2%, respectively, which were much higher than that of disodium naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate (Φf = 7.7%). The enhancement of luminescence of 1-3 compared to G1 can be analyzed from their crystal structures. In MOCs 1-3, G1 molecules were distributed orderly in the interlayer region, between polymer chains, or in the void of the 3D framework, which prohibited the aggregation-caused quenching of fluorophores. The different fluorescence intensity for MOCs 1-3 may be due to the different arrangements of G1 in 1-3. In MOC 1, naphthalene-2,7-disulfonates were confined between neighboring layers to form a flat layer through hydrogen-bonding interactions (d); G1 in 2 composed a 2D layer (Figure S2a), while in 3, G1's were connected together to generate a 3D structure (Figure S3). Hence, we provided herein an effective methodology to design and prepare luminescent materials by introducing fluorescent guest compounds into MOCs to obstruct the formation of luminophoric aggregates. If proper MOC and functional guests were combined together efficiently, more and more potential luminescent hybrid materials should be prepared.

elements.content: Second harmonic generation active metal–organic materials, combining the properties of the organic ligands and metal ions, have attracted great interest due to their potential applications in information storage, electric-optical devices, and light modulators. Because 1 and 3 crystallize in a noncentrosymmetric space group and 2 is chiral, their second-order nonlinear optical properties were studied. Second-harmonic generation on microcrystalline samples of 1–3 was carried out by using the Kurtz–Perry method using a Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) at room temperature. The results show that complexes 1a, 1b, 2, and 3 display SHG efficiencies, which are about 0.58, 0.42, 0.32, and 0.52 times that of KDP powder in the particle size of 106–150 μm ( ). The change tendency of NLO properties seems closely related to the structures, so we not only can prepare controllably the diverse MOC structures but also can adjust the NLO properties via altering the amount of DEF solvent in this system.
elements.clean_text:
Nonlinear Optical Properties

Second harmonic generation active metal-organic materials, combining the properties of the organic ligands and metal ions, have attracted great interest due to their potential applications in information storage, electric-optical devices, and light modulators. Because 1 and 3 crystallize in a noncentrosymmetric space group and 2 is chiral, their second-order nonlinear optical properties were studied. Second-harmonic generation on microcrystalline samples of 1-3 was carried out by using the Kurtz-Perry method using a Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) at room temperature. The results show that complexes 1a, 1b, 2, and 3 display SHG efficiencies, which are about 0.58, 0.42, 0.32, and 0.52 times that of KDP powder in the particle size of 106-150 μm ( ). The change tendency of NLO properties seems closely related to the structures, so we not only can prepare controllably the diverse MOC structures but also can adjust the NLO properties via altering the amount of DEF solvent in this system.

elements.content: In summary, three novel metal–organic complexes have been self-assembled under ambient conditions. MOC 1 is a 2D layered network, with disulfonate anions intercalated to the interlayer region. 2 is a 1D infinite linear chain, as one pyridine in hydrogenated Schiff base ligand L is uncoordinated. 3 is a 3D CdSO4-like framework, and disulfonate G1 distributed orderly in its voids. MOCs 1–3 crystallize in noncentrosymmetric or chiral space groups Pc, P21, and Cc, respectively. The constructions of such different structures of 1–3 are controlled by the amount of DEF solvent, which highlights a subtle solvent-induced self-assembly in crystal engineering. Furthermore, MOCs 1–3 show strong photoluminescence originating from naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate, and the emissions are enhanced greatly compared with that of free disulfonates. Therefore, introducing fluorescent molecules into metal–organic complexes is demonstrated as an effective strategy for the design and preparation of solid-state luminescent hybrid materials. Other diverse metal–organic architectures based on a hydrogenated Schiff base ligand and their applications are under investigation in our group.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three novel metal-organic complexes have been self-assembled under ambient conditions. MOC 1 is a 2D layered network, with disulfonate anions intercalated to the interlayer region. 2 is a 1D infinite linear chain, as one pyridine in hydrogenated Schiff base ligand L is uncoordinated. 3 is a 3D CdSO4-like framework, and disulfonate G1 distributed orderly in its voids. MOCs 1-3 crystallize in noncentrosymmetric or chiral space groups Pc, P21, and Cc, respectively. The constructions of such different structures of 1-3 are controlled by the amount of DEF solvent, which highlights a subtle solvent-induced self-assembly in crystal engineering. Furthermore, MOCs 1-3 show strong photoluminescence originating from naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate, and the emissions are enhanced greatly compared with that of free disulfonates. Therefore, introducing fluorescent molecules into metal-organic complexes is demonstrated as an effective strategy for the design and preparation of solid-state luminescent hybrid materials. Other diverse metal-organic architectures based on a hydrogenated Schiff base ligand and their applications are under investigation in our group.

Synthesis of [ZnL­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>·G1·DEF·2H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1a</bold>)

A solution of L (48 mg, 0.2 mmol) and Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O (74 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O/EtOH (6 mL/3 mL) was stirred for 10 min. Then, 3 mL of DEF and a solution of naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate (G1) (66 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (4.5 mL) was added. cln_elements.content:
In order to confirm the phase purity of these complexes, the PXRD patterns were recorded for MOCs 1 to 3. The experimental PXRD patterns of MOCs 1–3 are in good agreement with the simulated ones calculated from the single-crystal diffraction data (Figures S5–S7, Supporting Information), indicating that they are in a pure phase. Moreover, the thermogravimetric (TG) measurements were performed in a N2 atmosphere to examine the thermal stability. TG curves of MOCs 1–3 are shown in Figures S8–S11 (Supporting Information). MOCs 1–3 remained stable up to 311, 308, 318, and 274 °C, respectively. The TGA curve of complex 1a indicated that the loss of H2O and DEF molecules occurred between 85 and 286 °C (found 21.1%, calcd 21.8%), while the loss of H2O and DMA molecules in 1b occurred between 81 and 273 °C (found 20.8%, calcd 21.1%). In complex 2, a weight loss of 24.0% (calcd 24.3%) was observed with respect to the losses of water and DEF molecules between 65 and 271 °C, while a weight loss of 11.1% (calcd 10.8%) between 56 and 167 °C was observed for 3 with respect to the loss of water molecules.

Luminescence Properties

The photoluminescent properties of MOCs 1–3 together with naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate were investigated under ambient temperature. Upon excitation at 276 nm, strong emission bands centered at 342 and 358 nm were detected, which were similar to the emissions of naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate. So, the emissions of 1–3 may be assigned to the intraligand charge transition of sulfonate. The external quantum yields (Φf) of MOCs 1a, 1b, 2, and 3 were determined by means of an integrating sphere and found to be 20.3%, 14.3%, 19.7%, and 12.2%, respectively, which were much higher than that of disodium naphthalene-2,7-disulfonate (Φf = 7.7%). The enhancement of luminescence of 1–3 compared to G1 can be analyzed from their crystal structures. In MOCs 1–3, G1 molecules were distributed orderly in the interlayer region, between polymer chains, or in the void of the 3D framework, which prohibited the aggregation-caused quenching of fluorophores. The different fluorescence intensity for MOCs 1–3 may be due to the different arrangements of G1 in 1–3. In MOC 1, naphthalene-2,7-disulfonates were confined between neighboring layers to form a flat layer through hydrogen-bonding interactions (d); G1 in 2 composed a 2D layer (Figure S2a), while in 3, G1’s were connected together to generate a 3D structure (Figure S3). Hence, we provided herein an effective methodology to design and prepare luminescent materials by introducing fluorescent guest compounds into MOCs to obstruct the formation of luminophoric aggregates. If proper MOC and functional guests were combined together efficiently, more and more potential luminescent hybrid materials should be prepared.
